Executive summary for Risk Management Program  

1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

INEOS takes its responsibility for the environment very seriously and is fully committed to delivering a record of responsible environmental performance across all operations.  INEOS continually strives to meet and where practicable exceed strict safety, health and environmental performance targets and is committed to continuous improvement in all aspects of its operations.  Excellence in safety, health and environmental performance is INEOS? top priority.  INEOS is open and honest about such performance, which is published locally and nationally, as required.

INEOS operates to strict regulations that are set by the national environment agencies of the countries in which they operate.  INEOS is committed to ensuring that their facilities have as low an impact as possible on local people and the environment and continue to work in close partnership with community groups and other stakeholders to ensure that they are a responsible neighbor.

INEOS? commitment is to protect the health and safety of our employees, the communities in which they operate and the users of their products.  INEOS aims to meet or where practicable exceed all relevant legislative requirements and minimize the effect of their operations on the environment.

Active employee and contractor involvement is critical to achieving safety, health, and environmental objectives.  Employees and contractors throughout the Company participate in safety teams, contribute to investigations and incident learning, and suggest ongoing improvements in safety standards and procedures. 

INEOS commitment to safety starts at the top as a core value of the company.  It is driven through the Executive Boards of each of INEOS? 19 businesses, w

hich are accountable for performance, to all plant operating teams, wherever they are in the world.  INEOS supports a positive and open environment across their businesses, supported by effective communication between management, employees and contractors and an ongoing program of investment in safety.

INEOS management teams and employees know that the sustainable long-term future of their businesses rests on their track record on safety, health and the environment.  INEOS views safety, health and the environment as the top priority of all INEOS companies.

2.  FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The facility manufactures plastics and resins.  The plastic pellet products are sold to molders for end use in refrigerator and automobile interiors, medical uses, computer housings, health spas, tools, and much more. The resins are used to coat circuit boards and coat aluminum cans to allow printing on the can.

Two RMP chemicals are used in the facility, acrylonitrile and butadiene.  These make up two of the three main chemicals used to make the plastic products.  (The third being styrene a non-RMP chemical).  Acrylonitrile is a liquid and stored in two tanks prior to being used in smaller tanks and in several plastic manufacturing processes.  Butadiene is stored under pressure in a tank.  All storage tanks have concrete dike floors and walls capable of holding more than the quantity of the material being stored.  Multiple processes use these chemicals in various quantities in a process at one time.   Acrylonitrile is the only toxic RMP chemical and represents the worst case scenario for toxic chemicals.  Butadiene is the only flammable RMP chemical and thus represents the worst case flammable scenario.
 
3A. WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst case scenario for acrylonitrile assumes the following:
?    Greatest quantity of acrylonitrile is release from the largest storage tank over a 10 minute period.
?    The release is into the concrete dike which reduces the

impact of the spill.
?    The release occurs during worst case weather conditions.
?    All safety precautions and emergency response at the facility fail.

The worst case scenario for butadiene for west receptors assumes the following:
?    Greatest quantity of butadiene is instantly released from one railroad car.
?    The released vapors are ignited and explode.
?    All safety and emergency response precautions at the facility fail.

The second worst case scenario for butadiene exists for a set of east receptors and assumes the following:
?    Greatest quantity of butadiene is instantly released from the storage tank.
?    The released vapors are ignited and explode.
?    All safety and emergency response precautions at the facility fail.

3B. ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The alternative case scenario for acrylonitrile assumes the following:
?    Release is from an emergency vent release from a manufacturing process vessel.
?    Typical weather conditions (as provided by EPA)

The alternative case scenario for butadiene assumes the following:
?    A gasket in a pipeline fails and releases butadiene.   
?    Sensors detect butadiene and operators respond immediately.
?    The released butadiene vapor is ignited
?    Typical weather conditions (as provided by EPA)

4.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

This facility is an OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR site, one of the highest Safety Awards given.  Under the VPP, OSHA has recognized this facility as having exceptional safety process, programs, and performance.  Here is a list of some of those safe practices:


ENGINEERING and DESIGN
?    Detailed operating procedures
?    Special equipment standards
?    Special flanges, piping, valves
?    Remotely operated isolation valves
?    State of the art computerized controls, including alarm systems for early warning of problems
?    Redundant & energy protected controls
?    Control Room protection during emergencies
?    Inventory minimized for hazardous materials

?    Continuous improvement of processes & equipment
?    Hazard review for changes
?    Color coding and labeling of piping & vessels
?    Dikes and curbs to contain spills 
?    Emergency tank to contain system upsets
?    Spot ventilation system
?    Continuous process analyzers
?    Production units designed to withstand natural disasters
 
DETECTION
?    Process and storage tank area monitoring for acrylonitrile and butadiene
?    Control room air intake monitoring
?    Portable monitors for leak detection
?    Intense vessel inspection program (Internal and external)

TRAINING
?    Refresher and safety training for all employees
?    New employee qualification requirements
?    Regular emergency response drills
?    Specialized maintenance skills training
?    Worker certification programs
?    Off-site specialized training for emergency response teams    
INSPECTIONS and SAFETY REVIEWS
?    Incident investigations and reviews
?    Systematic equipment inspection
?    Critical instrument and pressure relief valve inspections
?    Process Hazard Analyses program
?    Fugitive emissions monitoring program
?    Safety audits of operating units
?    Tracking system for recommendations
?    Special permits required prior to maintenance work

MEDICAL MANAGEMENT
?    Certified EMTs 
?    Physician on site 
?    Physician?s nurse on site
 
MITIGATION
?    Release containment equipment and materials at each unit
?    Neutralization and decontamination procedures
?    Fire water monitor guns near process and storage tanks 
?    Foam vapor suppression capability

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
?    Trained emergency spill response teams
?    Written emergency action plans
?    Fire brigade maintained on all shifts that process units are operating
?    Fire brigade annual training and special training at Texas A&M Fire School
?    Emergency alarm systems coded to expedite rapid emergency response
?    Coordination with Addyston Emergency Operations Plan, LEPC, Hamilton County Emergency Management Agency, and local Fire Departments
?    Agreements with emergency response companies

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

?    Periodic reviews of operating procedures
?    INEOS employees make up 100% of emergency teams
?    Employees participate on incident investigation teams
?    Union employee safety trainers

The worst case scenarios are extremely unlikely events because of these extensive safety precautions in place at this facility.
 
5.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There were no reportable accidents in the last five years at the facility. 

6.     EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

This facility has extensive emergency response capabilities and coordinates with outside agencies.  Here is a summary of these capabilities.
?    All employees are trained for first level emergency response.
?    Trained fire brigade members are on site on all shifts that process units are operating.
?    Fire trucks are present on site which includes foam capability.
?    Coordination exists with local Fire Departments.
?    A plant siren sounds for every plant alarm.  The alarm is coded to expedite response by the plant fire chief and emergency fire brigade.  The alarm is tested weekly.
?    The City of Addyston Mayor and police department are notified on critical fire alarms along with other facilities as needed.
?    Emergency drills are conducted.
?    Public can be notified of chemical accidents through civil defense sirens, emergency weather radios, loud speakers on fire department vehicles or door-to-door notification via the Addyston Emergency Operations Plan.
?    Emergency communications are coordinated with local communities. 
 
7.     PLANS TO IMPROVE SAFETY

This facility continues to improve its safety.  Here are the primary methods:
?    Routine Process Hazards Audits are conducted on every operating process safety management (PSM) unit in the plant.  Detailed audits recommendations are made to improve the safety of the process.
?    New equipment is designed to the most modern safety standards and generally replaces older equipment.  
?    Employees continue to provide specific safety suggestions to improve the safety of equipment, procedures

, and processes.  
?    The plant works with Addyston and surrounding response agencies to improve communications with emergency responders and the public should a chemical emergency occur.
